His job to continue the reinvention of AWS and in turn, Amazon. Joining me on this edition of Bloomberg Studio 1.0, new AWS CEO, Adam Salipski. the time to market advantage that we had, which was probably honestly five to seven years, head start before other companies really started to take this seriously, and frankly, it was just one of the biggest things that happened to us in the early years. They said in the November statement, they've done a lot and they want to see how the rate hikes are impacting the economy. So, Richard, you have the advantage of having been in the room and having been in the room relatively recently. And you know, the challenge that the Fed faces and other central banks in the world is that the economy is running hot. And in particular, wages in the economy are growing much faster than consistent with the 2% longer run goal. And so, I think that the Fed will be looking at the labor market data. It'll also be looking at inflation expectations. We have downshifted demand growth. You know, there's an imbalance between demand and supply. And this year, demand growth has already downshifted. So, that's an important thing to note. We're certainly along the way to where we need to be. But the Fed has more to do and we need to get inflation back down towards the 2% objective. What determines that terminal rate? And let me ask you, perhaps more pointedly, some people think the Fed was a little slow getting off the market and getting going. Does the slowness of getting started mean the terminal rate would have to be higher necessarily? David, I don't think so. I think what launching the rate heights in March did mean. And I think Chair Powell recognized this.

David, I don't think so. I think what launching the rate heights in March did meet, and I think Chair Powell recognized this pretty early on, was that it made sense to get to the destination pretty quickly. And that's why we've had the four successive 75 basis point hikes. My sense right now is the committee believes, and I share the view that my baseline view is I want to get the funds rate around 5% if the inflation data comes in on the soft side, maybe four and three quarters. So I think that I wouldn't call that necessarily the terminal rate. I hope it is. If the inflation data doesn't improve, then they may have to do more. But I think they will cause at around 5%. to expect to do that. And obviously, pulling out of some old economy sectors or reducing it not to zero, but there is a shift in the banking wallet and we respond to that. So thank you for being here. It's great to be here. You basically grew up in a restaurant as I understand it. What was it like leaving China moving to Illinois and starting this new life? We immigrated to Illinois, Champaign, or Banna. My dad got his degree at the University of Illinois. My mom put food on the table by working three jobs a day, one of which did happen to be in a Chinese restaurant where I moonlight it as a dishwasher. So I got to hang out with mom that way as a way of growing up and I did that. I didn't understand what it meant to live off of food stamps to buy groceries or free and reduced lunch, you know, every day inside school. But it was a very empowering feeling to buy my own Nintendo or earn my way to buy my first Apple computer. The second thing was really just the power of independent thinking. Jack Dorsey and Keith were were trying to convince me to leave Stanford and work at Square full time. It was a fun and busy period of my time, but I enjoyed both. The idea for Dordash really came from this, you know, lifelong interest in helping these physical business owners, really people like my mom. So we talked to hundreds of small business owners and it was surprising to us that even in 2013, delivery was not a solved problem. There were business owners who would show us literally booklets of delivery orders.

And frankly, a necessary one, and that really became the impetus to start DoorDash. You started out driving for competitors, right? Do we do the right thing and refund every single customer, which would have cost us about 40% of our bank account, or do a less right thing and survive another day. Because it was very hard for us at that time to raise capital, which was something true for Door Ashes early history. And it took us about 30 seconds to click, submit, refund.
